Akiba's Trip: Undead and Undressed (Akiba's Trip 2), is a game where you strip vampires out in the open so that their skin may be exposed to direct sunlight. Sounds about as ridiculous as it gets, aye, but there's plenty of fun to be had, even in all the problems that this game brings.

I first heard about this game on Amazon, before it released in the West on the PS3. I bought this game on Steam when it was on sale. That said, the Steam port was my first experience with this game.

The first thing I noticed was the system requirements for this game. An i5? GTX 760? What kind of game is this?

Upon booting it up, I was greeted with a window which allowed me to map controls, change the game and voice language, set the resolution, change the number of NPCs rendered at a time, and turn VSync or anti-aliasing on... and that's it. There are no other PC specific options throughout the entire game. The game is even capped at 30 FPS with occasional drops, which really makes me wonder if the system requirements were because of the NPCs or port-job. This game is also really hard to play on the mouse and keyboard, so a controller is highly recommended.
Strangely enough, the controller buttons in this port show the XBox buttons, like A,B, X, and Y, even though this game was never released for XBox systems.
The PC port is a port of the PS4 version, which includes the DLC in-game already, faster NPC and area load times, and the Visual Editor, which is awesome. You can change the saturation of colors, or even just invert everything.

After starting a new game, it took me to a character model editor. Limited options are available at first, and more are unlocked as you play and complete routes, including the option to change clothes on different characters, change their voices, and even their entire model altogether.

Before I go any further, I'd like to point out that I played this game with Japanese voices, so I can't make any comments on the English voice-over. For the Japanese voices, as expected, everything sounds top-notch. However, I did find the weak male" voice to be incredibly annoying

reviewText:
It is not a great port: small locations, low draw distance, 30 FPS lock, lack of details, low texture quality, but it is still a good and enjoyable game with criminally low sales. You definitely should buy it, if you want more of this cute Japanese nonsense on Steam.

You can call this game “a small sand box”. You will run around Akihabara, collecting flyers for real stores and cafes (when you finally go to Japan and visit these shops they'll all, probably, be out of business), completing side missions (fighting and undressing 48 young idols, helping a modern Romeo & Juliet by fighting and undressing theirs relatives, buying cakes for your little sister), and beating random strangers with an LCD monitor and stealing their clothes just because you can.

Story & side missions: reasonably weird and fun, but somewhat repetitive — almost all missions require you to fight someone (and steal their clothes).

Gameplay: solid and fast-paced action with good controls. However, difficulty can be a little bit too low. I recommend to use gamepad.

Characters: my little sister likes to pretend that she is a jet. Which is lovely.

Another problem, fortunately it doesn't really appear until you play the game on higher difficulty settings such as Gamer and Otaku mode is that during major fights, the view can become blocked by scenery or the entire viewpoint can shift completely.

Everything else about the game though is positive,  their are many different endings - a huge amount of character customization, lots of different and wacky weapons to use although, a few weapons are a bit overpowered.   The story and character design is very good, alot of emotional scenes and interesting areas of Akihabara to discover.

reviewText:
The Short of It: Recommended if - and only if - you're not looking for a deep and engaging storyline or a finely-polished seamless combat system. Akiba's Trip: Undead and Undressed is not that kind of game. Rather, it is a goofy, utterly silly romp that never takes itself, the entire JRPG genre or otaku culture seriously. Also not recommended if you're a prissy prude who thinks showing underwear is more morally reprehensible than blowing people's heads apart.



The Long of It: Akiba's Trip is the story of Nanashi, a young man who wastes his time watching anime DVDs and hoarding figurines. His life of couch-potatoism comes to an end when he is turned into a Synthister, a type of vampire-alike who drain people's life force and dissolve in the sun. He is rescued from the evil bad guy's laboratory by Shizuku, and together with her and his loser otaku friends, Nanashi sets out to bring justice to the creators of the Synthisters.

The Synthisters' weakness defines the way they should be battled, since they protect themselves from the sunlight by wearing clothes. Why they don't simply walk around only at night is a mystery. Regardless, their weakness and immunity to physical punishment means Nanashi has to defeat them by exposing them to the sunlight... by, yes, ripping off their clothes. Now, this may sound like it's a petty excuse for fanservices, and yes, it is - but the game's entire tone and atmosphere is a parody on JRPG's, and this whole setup fits the mood perfectly.

Also pretty nifty is that XSeed have actually modeled the game world after Akihabara (Japan's nerd capital) faithfully, and the enviroments can stand the comparison with actual Akihabara, right down to the shops and businesses, all exactly the same and in the exact same location as real-life Akiba. It adds a lot of spirit to a game to know that it's set in an actual city.



The Right of It: Akiba's Trip makes no excuses about being nerdy, silly and just the right amounts of lame, and its whole comical setup is delivered in all aspects, not just the storyline and characters, but the weapons, the techniques, the combat animations, the entire thing is just made for goofy fun. Nanashi is anything but a fighting man, and his attacks are clumsy and dorky, and always funny to watch, as are those of his enemies. Almost every weapon has a unique set of animations, and a lot of the fun in this game is just beating your opponents over the head while wielding a giant leek, a collection box, cheerleader's pompoms, a kebab stick or any of the other ridiculous weapons. The stripping animations, too, are full of goofiness and anime and video game references.

When fighting Synthisters, you can involve just about any passerby in the battle just by hitting them a few times. With some persistent aggression, you can turn a one-on-one battle into a full-on mass brawl where everyone rips everyone's clothes off. Few things are quite as satisfying.



The Wrong of It: Akiba's Trip's humour may not be to everyone's taste. People who want serious games should definitely abstain, and the effect might not resonate with people not really familiar with JRPGs.

As said before, the combat and game system is more attuned to silliness than it is to balanced and challenging gameplay, so don't expect the polished combat you'll find in other action games, don't expect to play a game that is 'easy to learn and difficult to master' - it is not that kind of game. The difficulty, too, isn't made for forehead-knotting challenges, but simply for good hilarious fun.

Many people will also claim the game is short, and it can be - you can finish the entire story in two hours if you rush - but those people are simply playing the game wrong. The game's intention is not to let you do side quests until you're ready to take on the Big Bad, the side missions are simply meant to be done for the fun of doing them. So don't rush through it and then complain the game is short.



The Last of It: Don't think this is a game for perverts or people with ♥♥♥♥ fantasies. If you play it, you'll see that it's really no heavier on the fanservice than 'normal' JPRGs, and that the whole stripping thing is more funny than it is pervy. Definitely give it a miss if JRPGs aren't your kind of game, or if you're looking for a spectacular, smoothly playing and hair trigger-responsive beat-'em-up. Pass on this one if you like spending your time on tumblr whining and crying about misogyny and the patriarchy.

Do give it a try if you think you'll like a game that makes fun of all the JRPG and anime tropes and approaches fanservice and otaku fetishes in a humorous way.

Akiba's Trip is a somehwhat odd but ultimately lighthearted (most of the time) game, that intentionally plays into traditional anime tropes because it's a celebration of the culture as a whole. Aside from a few cringe worthy references here and there which I imagine aren't in the original japanese translation, the game ultimately feels like a love letter to otaku culture and isn't afraid to poke fun at it or deconstruct it briefly in the meantime; I swear while reading pitter in this game that I somehow found my way back to a chan website in the middle of the game.

You can tell this game was made on a budget since some side missions are re used by the end of the game with merely an increase in difficulty and a different reward and the story is presented to you via Visual Novel like appearance. On top of this, the combat system is a bit repetitive but when you think of it more like a turn based RPG with brawler elements with a heavy emphasis on crowd control instead of a brawler with RPG elements, it makes a lot more sense within it's context that it'd have repetitive animation as turn based RPGs usually do.

Akiba's Trip is still a genuinely enjoyable experience though if you're into JRPGs as a whole, however. The writing is often flippant, witty and also intentionally campy; Just reading item descriptions is an enjoyable experience in this game. The characters are likeable (Except for Rin although she gets some redemption in the game), there's a lot of custimization, even down to the color pallete of the game itself and what animations your partner uses.

There's not a lot as utterly hilarious as giving your partner a thug walk/idle animation and having them follow you around starting ♥♥♥♥ with random synthisters, which are the antagonists of this game. Basically the reason you have to strip the clothes off of your enemies is because they're vampires of a unique brand who will burn up in the sun only when their clothes are removed.

If you like stuff in this vein, I.E. stuff like Persona or Yakuza, or you like visual novels and or immersive Playstation 2-era JRPGs then you'll like akiba's trip. If you can't stand things like anime archetypes, even though they're presented more subtly here you probably you won't like this game.

All in all, I'd give it a decent 7.50/10, my first playthrough doing every side quest I could see took me about 35 hours. The game's worth your time if you like JRPGs or just colorful light hearted settings. And besides, this game is previously a playstation exclusive; Having it come to PC is kind of a big deal, I just wish it wasn't locked at 30 fps. I forgive it though because it's supposed to be emulating an anime art style, and that ♥♥♥♥'s usually at 24.

The port runs fine for me. No complaints. The frame rate is not amazing but the console version never did any better, and the PC version can handle four times the people crowding the streets.

I've played this extensively on the PS3 so what follows is my experience from that.

Part love letter to otaku culture and Akihabara, part goofy comedy, with a dash of Yakuza and Gladiator Begins, Akiba's Trip is hard to describe easily. A loving recreation of Japan's nerdiest district, trying, not always successfully, to imbue it with a sense of wonder and mystery, with all the sorts of crazy characters you might expect to see in such a place, from overwrought lolitas to tsundere idols to obsessed otakus to goofy foreigners excited to drink in the culture. The nonstop ads for animes, video games, and the like providing the background noise as you wander the streets. The worldcraft is not as good as GTA or Yakuza, but there's something to like about this virtual Akihabara.

The actual gameplay is just as charming, and just as rough around the edges. It's an action-RPG beat-em-up where you aim to damage an opponent's clothes enough to tear them off. While there is not a lot of skill to the system, your weapons always hit with a satisfying thunk, thwack, or clank, and most combats involve you trying to weaken every enemy's clothes to set up for a massive chain strip, which gives the combat a satisfying meta-game where the simple guards, counters, and guard breaks don't otherwise provide much to go with. Naturally, you want to collect every type of clothing and weapon you can to fill out those collectible books.

Side-quests, exploration, multiple endings based on which girl you end up with, the game is quite short but meant to be replayed. The difficulties then are built more around your level gear than your own skill, but the game exercises one bit of brilliance here: Your XP is reset each game. So you can always redo a low difficulty without being overpowered play just by shelving your overpowered 999 weapons and clothes and crafting up something from scratch again, whereas if you need to take on the high difficulties, you can always whip out the good gear again.

If you have a heart that likes charming, unpretentious, and goofy anime schlock, you should enjoy Akiba's Trip.

reviewText:
Normally I don't finish games, but this game was so enjoyable and rewarding I felt the need to finish all four (technically 5) routes. The story is great, and the humor and references are always fun. The stripping (combat) is done relatively well. There's tons of costumes (and underwear) to dress you and your partners in. It's not a typical JRPG by any means; it's all about fun. When you can always occupy yourself with fun sidequests, there isn't that much of a grind. Once you get through your first playthrough, it's pretty much smooth sailing from there (unless you play on Otaku mode, which I don't suggest unless you have maxed out gear).

There's a huge variety of weapons, most of which aren't real weapons. Toys, computer parts, umbrellas, hug pillows, figurines, and much more. It's just another thing that gives the game its unique appeal. Even after 4+ playthroughs, I didn't discover all the weapons in the game... somehow. There's always new stuff to find, which gives the game great replayability value. You can use a Hyperdimension Neptunia dakimakura as a weapon, 'nuff said.


I only have two complaints about this game:

1. It's capped to 30fps. Don't get me wrong, it looks perfectly fine the way it is, but it *could* look better (especially in terms of texture resolution, but that's to be expected of a Vita port). There's guides on how to get it up to 60fps, but it makes the fighting buggy to the point where it's almost unplayable... and for me, it's not a stable 60fps, so it's just not doable. The game relies on real-time combat, so if I can't properly see what's going on, I'm dead. And that brings me to the second problem:

2. If you get surrounded, you're screwed. It can happen even if you're using the most OP sword in the game you get after you finish your first playthrough: you're going to be hit multiple times a second, your clothes are going to lose tons of durability, and you'll have a ton of trouble escaping. Jumping doesn't do anything, so you'll be constantly knocked to the ground until you're lucky enough to push a bunch of people back at once. It becomes a huge problem in late-game fights, and it forces me to constantly use attacks that knock enemies down, which makes the fights take a lot longer. Thankfully, the healing mechanic allows you to recover, assuming you can find a spot to hide in for about 3 seconds.

2.5. This makes blocking useless most of the time. If you block attacks from one person, others will start to attack, and the moment you let go of the block button, you're likely to get knocked back. I got through all routes without ever blocking for this reason. The counterattack achievement (for blocking and then retaliating) is one of the few achievements I don't have for this game because of that.


Other than that, the game is great. I highly recommend it. Just make sure to play with a controller and with Japanese audio. My suggested playthrough order is: Tohko, Shizuku, Rin, Shion. Nana's bonus route/ending can be achieved with each of them. You don't have to take a bath with her for it, but I suggest that too.

reviewText:
Firstly, let me start off by saying that I was very hesitant to buy this. I had never played a game like this and the concept of stripping people as the main form of combat sounded a bit too weird to me. In the end I decided to purchase it because I am a fan of anime art style, and boy am I glad that I did.

Akiba's Trip is set in Tokyo's Akihabara district, also known as the holy land for otaku worldwide. In the game, you travel back and forth between accurately reconstructed areas of Akiba. Although the game is not totally free roam, like say, Skyrim, it felt much more alive and populated as NPC tourists, high school students, fanboys, lolitas and more travel through the various zones. Billboards broadcast anime and gaming adverts, there are many shops, and you can even receive flyers for real life places in Akihabara.

The combat of the game is ridiculously fun and addictive (a controller is highly recommended). Your enemies in the game are synthesisters (more or less man-made vampires), so of course it makes sense to strip them in daylight instead of using something more practical like a wooden stake or crossbow, right? Right?? Anyway, you target the enemies' legs, torsos and heads during combat, using one of a multitude of upgradeable weapons, and then when you have done enough damage, tear their clothes off. Clothes act as armour and you can dress however you want, as well as you can upgrade your favourite clothes.

The game even has its own version of twitter, where you can read tweets and be immersed in otaku internet culture. You also have an email system with useful info that gets sent to you, and the occasional laugh from some of them. For more immersion, the game's version of a character hideout or base is a nice internet cafe where you can play arcade games.

Lastly, the replayibility of this game is superb. After finishing the main storyline once (oh yes, and there are tons of sidequests to enjoy), there is a new game plus mode where you can unlock new difficulties, as well as character models and multiple new endings to discove as your responses to certain girls will determine which ending you get. it's also worth noting that you get to keep your previous gear when starting again.

I would highly recommend Akiba's Trip. The game is highly customisable, addictive and has a unique atmosphere. Just make sure you try the free demo before buying the game to make sure there are no major technical issues. 10/10

reviewText:
I don't really know where to start with this game.  The port is a little shabby, framerate locked at 30, limited options, some crashing issues, but passable.
The real issue is just that Akiba's Trip: Undead & Undressed is a hot mess.  The developers seem to insist on having knowledge that videogames exist, what with the real ads for other jrpgs playing on the TVs in the game world constantly, the painful self-referential dialogue, the story right off of tvtropes.com/anime, but at the same time it feels like they've never actually played one before.

The combat system is clunky, and seems to ignore all the progress video games have made up to this point.  You are locked into attack strings, sidestepping exists but is almost functionally worthless, locking on (and the camera is general) is very messy, and the AI leaves a hell of a lot to be desired.  The combat will generally boil down to button mashing or counter spamming until you get smashed by some dishonest unblockable hitbox or gangbang, goading you to run away and heal, rinse and repeat.  The combat could have been much less hollow and unenjoyable with a few simple tweaks like being able to cancel attack strings with blocks/sidesteps, perfect parries, some i-frames on the evades, and other general stuff that almost every beat em up and stylish action game that exists in this day and age has.  It feels almost like the expectation was that the game's lackluster combat systems would be carried by the premise that instead of beating up people you are ripping up their clothes, and instead of normal game weapons you are using wacky, random everyday objects.

Similar to The World Ends with You, the setting for Akiba's Trip is a real place in Japan (the Akihabara district in the Chiyoda ward of Tokyo), and the game insists on giving you a virtual tour of the place at any chance they get.  NPCs will hand out flyers in-game of real life businesses in the area and the game constantly dotes on the place to the point where how awesome it is and how many otakus hang out there becomes a core point in the plot.  I was very suprised to see the game was made by a real game development studio and not the Akihabara Tourist Information Center.

The game presents you with the surprisingly common 'potentially global serious issue that only these teenagers right here can solve', and a cast of varied, boring, stupid, and inconsistent characters to play around with.  You'll meet such memorable mainstays as
'little sister that regularly reminds you how adorable she is and hints at liking you a little too much but that's not weird at all because we're sick people'
'girl visiting japan from finnland with no accent speaking fluent japanese minus an issue she made once when they introduce the character to make it believable that one time'
'magical sisters that look like they aren't of legal age but because of that magic they're actually like 500 years old so it's ok to bang them or look at their panties or whatever'
'cool old guy that isn't like all the other adults'
'guy who plays a lot of video games and watches a lot of anime (just like us!) that can apply that knowledge to the inexplicable real-life-definitely-not-anime scenario we're in right now'
'self-depricating pasty anime loving protagonist that's supposed to be a thinly-veiled jab at you the player for some cheap jokes and maybe a little self-insertion masturbatory fantasy if you're really that far gone'
and definitely a couple others that defy my desire to keep this tired bit going.  Basically if you really do like this anime stuff you'll know all of these rascals from somewhere else and I assume it'll provide you with the equivalent thrill of seeing Brad Pitt in yet another movie.

One of my biggest peeves with Akiba's Trip was the writing, which scaled from 'we can all have a nice laugh at the expense of how bad this is' to 'I'm in physical pain at the realization that people have previously, are currently, and will continue to pay real money for the experience this moment is encompassed by'.  When i say the writing, I mean all of it- the plot structure, the dialogue, the quest logs, the item descriptions, ♥♥♥♥ing PITTER. It's similar in a sense to Borderlands 2- the game feels like it's just been written by a person with a bad, juvenile sense of humor and the inability to really express themself eloquently, like they're the kind of person that shouldn't be a writer.  In the case of Akiba's Trip it's an issue that goes beyond mediocre localization, you can really tell that the core game was plagued with inconsistent tone, an attachment to lazy 4th wall jokes, and a script made by a bunch of guys at the office getting blindfolded and throwing darts at an anime conventions bingo card.  When the player is presented with dialogue choices you get the formulaic Renegade, Paragon, or Completely Stupid Joke Answer triplets. Occasionally you're met with the classic Visual Novel choices of Girl A, Girl B, or Girl C assumedly to pad her favor for a chance at her unique ending.  Since you're a teenager your game's menu is replaced by a smartphone, and menu options are replaced by APPs.  You have a camera phone, you receive quest-related details and spam in your email inbox, and you can read up on current events in some hellish twitter-equivalent called Pitter.  Pitter does a really good job at summarizing what I can't stand about the writing in this game.  Feeding your player backstory by giving them fresh perspective via comment-board archetypes is incredibly lazy, it's a parody of the lowest common denominator.  From the very moment the game starts the player gets reminded that he has an unhealthy obsession with anime figurines and he never has sex.  A few hours of nerd-bashing later the game tries to put you into a 'real' anime story about super vampires sucking the life out of people and it's just so surrounded by ridiculous parodic humor and butt/boob jokes at that point that it's insulting to the player that anything is presented with a hint of seriousness.

From what I could tell, all the sidequests in this game are like that one sidequest in other games where you go to fetch something but it ends up being somewhere else three or four times, causing you to run around to multiple locations to pad out game time for very little effort on the developer's part.  I did the first nine or so sidequests before coming to the realization that they were all stupid and hollow and a lot more fetch-y than your average video game sidequests.  They're also all just a means to get more money, which has very little purpose since the stores sell a lot of redundant garbage- once you buy one new weapon and a set of clothes you're done for the course of the entire game unless you want to get really min/maxey.  Also one of my sidequests expired because the passage of time is tied to furthering the main quest and the place I had to turn in the side quest was where the main quest was and the main quest always takes priority when entering a zone so I had no choice but to fail the side quest in an attempt to complete the side quest.  It's all very headache-inducing.

There's also just loads of poorly-explained oddities and minor issues that I have with the game outside of the core issues that aren't really worth talking about, they just all add up to an unpleasant game experience.  I just played through the game asking myself when I would have fun.  Am I tired of the 20 second super attack animation yet?  Is the drop system supposed to make any sense?  Does there need to be six numbered versions of the same store on the same street that each only sell four or five items instead of just one big store?  Why am I prompted to start New Game+ before I even finish my playthrough?  What are the redeeming qualities of this game?

I really went into this game looking forward to an interesting beat em up with some unique mechanics, it just turned out to kinda suck.

reviewText:
Akiba's Trip (I swear the design at the title screen makes me think it's really Akiba Strip. Check it out if you don't believe me.) is certainly not something like everything else. That alone is the single most important reason why you would want to buy this game.

This is no Saint's Row or GTA but it can feel like one when you're doing the side quests.

Crossdressing to get guys to stop hitting on a girl? Only to kick the ♥♥♥♥ out of them for hitting on you? Hell YES!

Hunting down cursed urban hardware? Whuuuuut?

Stopping a labor law protest coming from 48 girls...only to beat all of them to death in a survival scenario?! (Forget stripping them! I'm UNDER ATTACK BY 48 GIRLS!)

Just...WOW....JUST...FREAKING...WOW JAPAN!

You start off as a guy that fell for a shady job and got turned into some kind of demi-vampire but you get saved by a random girl. (you learn more about her later and why.) After you get busted out you investigate this town which is actually a rl city from 80s Japan. Unfortunately other people are being turned into these demi-vampires, known as synthisters, and you have to best them in combat by ripping their clothes off so that the sunlight takes care of the rest. Simple....yet not so...

The game itself is a Aerial Camera 3D brawler. You control your camera with right stick and use 3 buttons for attacking the sections of your victim's bodies. Y for head, B for mid section, and A for low section. After you bust up the durability of your opponent's clothing enough you then hold one of the corresponding buttons for an attempt to rip off the clothing. So the combat is very simple and easy to pick up on. You can also use some special moves too with the different weapons available. To negotiate your targets the one your character will attack will have a ring around them when you align yourself before you start button mashing. Careful though, you're partially like the synthisters too and your opponents will be trying to strip you too. If you lose your headpiece/top/bottom altogether, you die. There's a lot more to the combat than just these. This is just the bread and butter stuff. There are counters and blocking and unblockable attacks.

This game has some kind of date sim/RPG story element into it in which it has several endings, all dependent on which of the girls you meet feels about you depending on the dialog choices you choose.

And mostly...that's pretty much it. The game is short but it does have a few problems.

First and foremost. The maps are very small.
To add to the very small maps. If you're forced into combat in these small streets or alleyways you can be shoved near the exit points as you're fighting. You won't automatically exit the map while in combat but the camera fixes and zooms out and does that almost instantly which isn't just annoying but also screws up your concentration and view. On my first dry run, it was frustrating but I guess it's something you can train yourself to get used to. You're doing to HATE places like Junk Street.

Secondly is how missions are handled. The main missions are instanced on their own map even though you travel to the map it's at. They start AUTOMATICALLY when you enter that map. It does save you the trouble of looking for an npc but that's where the problems with the side quests come in.

The side quests are marked by Red ! Points however the game has no local radar or any icons to view quest NPCs. In order to find quest npc objectives you have to make sure you have the Npc titles turned on. (Turn them on by pressing Y when not in combat and you'll see the npcs classes i.e. Otaku, Maid, Gothic Lolita, schoolgirl, etc.) Regular npcs are yellow titled and side quest/objective npcs are Red titled however with no radar some of them are hard to find and the side quests have expiration timers. You do get a good bit of time, don't get me wrong, but when players want to start something they shouldn't have to strain their eyes fishing for out of place NPCs in a sea of yellow words. On the plus side, because the maps are very small, this isn't as bad as it sounds.

All and all I think it's the closest Japan's coming to making a good and decent open world game but it still feels like it has it's constrictions but it's still nice. Grab it on sale...just don't tell your friends or your parents. :)

Now if you'll excuse me...I have a lot of sewing to do~

reviewText:
An enclosed world beat-em-up, if you thought damage equaled to how little cloths you have wearing.

Have you ever played the Yakuza series, on like the Sega Dreamcast? It's kind of like that but more free in choice. Combat gameplay is not restricted to story progression or random events, which means grinding is an option. Depending on how you want to play the game is like a progression of a visual novel game. With five different ending routes and an average story completion time of 15 hours, sometimes you wonder how a $30 game can be as fun as any new $60. Combat is determined by wits more than stats. Thanks to the game’s difficulty modes, even the hardest level that is unlocked by completion can end up tearing apart your most invested clothes considered untouchable.

The game shows you how to play though story progression tutorials. You can forcibly take off clothes or defend from grabs by mashing the attack button that targets that section. Use attacks or special moves that are unique to each weapon to wear down clothes that give off a color that can be instantly torn off. Or you can wait it out by doing a mix of both by challenging yourself to tear every clothing from multiple enemies though a quick time event that can end with a Justice theme pose, blinding lights, and hefty experience boost by getting more than 7 clothes.

The choice to go out alone or with a follower is up to you. Usually it’s easier with a follower that can help take the heat off of you or help with cloth stripping combos. Most of the time a follower is attached due to story progression.

The Game’s loot system is determined by how you play and how well you do it. You have a chance of keeping clothes that are taken instead of ripping them apart. A tough enemy can drop high level gear or unique items. This could be one of those games that get easier the better you play. If you lose your cloths, don’t panic, you can take them back if you defeat the enemy that took them. Or if your clothes got destroyed by taking any more damage while 0 on hit points can be repurchased at a unique shop.

This game features grinding because you can scan and target people on the street. Don't get carried away or else the police will arrest you at a moment of venerability for a fate worse than a game over, paying a fine that can cost more than a mission award.

This can be the closest to what is considered street fashion or cosplay, in a game of clothes stealing.

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun if you happen to be an otaku and browse certain image boards on a regular basis.

The dialogue is very relatable, and the new game + feature adds a lot of replay value if you're after certain achievements, dating routes, or a speedy completionist run.

The first issue that I encountered was that the game does not play well with triple monitor setups, or at least not with mine (6030x1080 GTX 970).  This is true with most, if not all console ports.  But with many console ports, multiple monitors will usually go into stand-by mode if you play at a single monitor resolution while at fullscreen.  Whereas with Akiba's trip, even at a single monitor resolution, the game will span all three monitors and zoom in.  The only workaround I found was to play the game in Windowed mode, or disable Nvidia Surround and play it on a single monitor.

Also, there is no option to change your controller schema or graphics resolution while in-game.  All resolution and controller tweaks are done on the launch menu.

If you're on a single monitor setup and you have a gamepad handy, then the amount of configuration and/or troubleshooting needed is minimal.  Even with these minor issues, I still had a lot of fun and would definitely recommend it to fellow otaku.

ATUU is super-couched in Japanese culture. When it's not a bizarre mix of comic otaku culture shenanigans and entirely softcore hentai, it's a visual novel and dating sim. The game features over 100 collectible flyers from real stores in Japan. Parts of it feel like the whole thing was cooked up by the Akihabara Tourism Board. If you couldn't care less about Japan and want a totally engaging, polished video game experience, this one isn't for you.

But for those who can appreciate what it is and where it comes from, there's something lovable about ATUU, and while the combat system can be frustratingly unpredictable, it's also part of what gives it its charm. After an intentional back-alley brawl turns into a seemingly endless mosh pit of clothes-stripping, glowstick-stabbing, laptop-pelvic-thrusting hijinks, you get a bit caught up in the game's chaotic sincerity, and the rest becomes just another vehicle for currying the favor of whichever girl you think is cutest. After all, as the Silent Male Protagonist, you are somehow both inexplicably irresistible, and devoid of all character traits--except those selected in certain conversational dialogue trees.

And then, of course, you dress up your waifu how you like and eventually earn special cut scenes of stripping her to her panties. Because hey, this is still Japan we're talking about, and games don't get much more modern-Japanese than this one right here.

Rather, Akiba Strip (let's not kid ourselves, that's the real name) is about... the plot, surprisingly enough, with a clumsy as hell combat system tacked on as the selling point. You've been kidnapped and turned into a vampire - sorry, synthister - that normally must feed on other people's positive energy, but thanks to a fateful blood pact you are able to retain your free will, and thusly go about your business of vaporizing other synthisters by stripping them of their clothing, exposing them to sunlight. It's equal opportunity pantsing of both genders whether you like it or not so it doesn't come across as horribly sexist, but for the majority of this game you go about brutally murdering your less fortunate kin via clothes removal with little hint of remorse. Rather morbid, really.

But that's okay because you get to buy keyboards and giant novelty items to use as weapons and it's slapstick ha ha and there's the mandatory forced romance subplot and... well at least the characters are amusing and the translation's good. Combat, sadly, is the worst attempt at a ripoff of the Arkham games I've yet seen, so again, the best you can hope for from this is an amusing story and lampooning of otaku culture. Does crash on load screens occasionally though.

If nothing else it's a comfort to know that I'm not quite so far gone as to identify with any of the wackjobs in this game in the slightest.

Pros:
- RPG with levels and Equipment stripping skill meters to grind up.

- Replayability everywhere!

- Does not have autosave, you must manually and save often.
- The anime / Japanese aesthetic may not be appealing to some.
- Don't let your friends see you playing this or you might be subject to extensive needling.

Having played this game extensively for one ending on the hardest starting difficulty, I think I can wholly write up a review on this thing now that I've stripped the grand majority of Akibahara's residents of their garments.

This game is something I'd say anyone could pick up and have a ball with. There are So many little things, such as all weapons having their own fighting style. Some share similarities but overall, every weapon is different in it's own way.

The environment itself, from the stores to the streets, are actual places from the real Akihabara in Japan. I personally thought that was a wonderful detail to the game and it makes it feel more alive.

Combat is pretty straight forward. One button hits one body part and the others hit whatever body part they correspond with. Smack the body in the part till the cover comes apart!

It does have a lack of variety in activities, but that doesn't seem to scuff the shine of this incredibly fun little experience. There is a large variety of side quests and an arena to spice things up.

The game does have some issues, though I have not experienced them. Issues like, crashing on start up, inability to get passed character creation and so forth. Most issues seem to be nothing more than crashing, so I'd advice that if the game works wonderfully for you, save, save and save often! I learned that the hard way, as the game has no autosave feature.

Want a score?
7.8/10 - Comes close to an 8, but if it was more polished with a bit more to do, perhaps better combat even, this would be an 8. Hands down.

My real score?
Fun/10 - Buy the game

-High replayability
-Tons of collectable clothes, weapons, accessories

reviewText:
A really fun little hybrid between character action game, RPG and dating sim / visual novel. Has a fun and unique combat system and one of the few games that I actually enjoyed playing on the highest difficulty.

Akiba's Trip is full of esoteric anime and Japanese culture references, mainly due to the fact that it's a highly detailed virtual recreation of the real life Akihabara in Japan. If you want a game where you can customise your character to look almost exactly how you want it to, then this game is for you.

I found this game to have some really interesting customisation options. From the generic Torso, Legs, Head and accessory slots, there's also a slot to customise how your character walks, and how your character finishes off enemies. In addition to this, upon completing the game you gain the ability to play as nearly every character in the game as your lead character. You can also customise other lead characters in this manner.

The customisation mentioned above is obviously bare-bones at the start, as your options increase as you unlock them through playing the game. Some options can only be unlocked after clearing the game, meaning replayability is through the roof as everything is unlocked after playing through the game about 6 or 7 times.

Aside from the interesting customisation system, replayability, and fun anime / game references; the gameplay is solid, easy to understand, fun and varied.

I found my favourite part of combat was trying out all of the different makeshift weapons, as every single one has its own moveset, animations and effects in combat. From what I can tell, there are over 100 different weapons, from wooden swords to laptops and dakimakura, that's a hell of a lot of combat variety. Even with all this variety, you end up finding a moveset you love, and for me it was my trusty ol' High Quality Wooden Sword (which I upgraded to godlike" status along my several playthroughs).

reviewText:
Put simply, AKIBA'S TRIP: Undead ＆ Undressed is a game about an otaku being mixed up in an incident and ends up saving the city.
It has a story similar to a mainstream anime with your typical anime trope girls (tsundere, childhood friend, cute sister etc).
The game delivers the plot through visual novel type story telling and feels like a mix between a dating sim and your average rpg where the hero saves the world.
The downside to the game seems to be the combat which can feel pretty clunky and fixed camera angles in certain places.
If you are an anime fan that likes your average hero saves the world story and getting cute girls, you should give this game a try.

Pros:
-Decent voice acting
-High replayability
-Tons of collectable clothes, weapons, accessories
-Alternate routes and endings depending on dialogue choices
-Getting a strip combo off can be very satisfying

Cons:
-Camera control can be awkward and is fixed near entrances making combat troublesome.
-Targeting can be a problem when facing large number of enemies.
-Combat can be annoying when facing large mobs as you are unable to dodge when attacking and can easily be attacked
-Experienced crashing when alt-tabbing out of game in full screen mode

-Summary of Entire Review-

Controller Needed = Yes
DLC and Microtransactions = No

Gameplay/Combat - 6.5 / 10
Music - 4 / 10
Story - 5 / 10
Customization - 9 / 10

-Its Gender Neutral - There are just as many fanservice shots of guys, as there are for girls. and the stripping effects everybody.
-You can Crossdress
-You can Collect underwear.
-You can dress up your allies in any clothes you collect/buy (And you can upgrade all clothing, so the tiny miniskirt and tube-top, is viable and you wont be puinished for bein a perv)
-Theres a TINY bit of Yuri
-The Cellphone Camera has a mode where you can get really close to the ground to get upskirt shots.
-One of the companions has a total Dom thing going, and you can buy Collars for erbody.

___________
-Actual Review-

When it comes to games, I'm a sucker for Cute Anime Girls, Extensive Customization, and Movement.
Upon seeing this game, I had pretty much instantly decided I was going to buy it.
I looked at the screenshots, and read a few reviews, and from what little I got from it all, I decidede it was a game I was going to buy, on sale.

Near Murican thanksgiving, I notice the numbers on the price have reversed order, and the $32 dollar game, is now $23, so I take my chance, and grab it then and there.

After playing it....I honestly would be fine saying its worth 32 bucks. at least for ME.

I didn't really think there would be much to it... some clothing customization, some weapons, boring as ♥♥♥♥ combat, and some fanservice...I thought I was buying a $10 game for double the price, but really theres a fair bit of detail in this game that I wasn't expecting.
At first, it was small things, like the fact there's an ongoing 'twitter' story, where lurkers of the internet have conversations about the events, you as the main character, are participating in...it expands the story a bit in a way, that makes sense, even if the story isnt anything really worthwhile, its a nice touch.

Then I noticed the Visual Editor settings, for the world itself. the ability to change more than just the contrast, but the tint of every shadow, the fog, the color of the sky, how much bloom and blur there is. you can change the colors and design of the world anytime. which, for most, is worthless crap. but for folks like me, its nice to know that at any time, I can change the world to become an eternal sunset, or even convert everything into pure black and white sillohuettes.

Then, began the Combat... Although its certainly not terrible, its also not all that fantastic either.
Attacks are focused on High, Medium, and Low. you damage the opponent's clothing before you rip it off of them...remove everything they have on, before your opponent, does the same to you.
Now, I like this system, because its the same for the player....your three main articles of clothing become your health bars. where reaching Zero is dangerous, but doesnt kill you.
However, where this falls apart, is in the weapons.
The game, does not take itself seriously, and it expects players to do the same. where this is an issue, is that, SOME weapons, attempt to be funny. forcing your combo to finish in a hilarious forward dive attack that leaves you on the ground for a few seconds. or converts your moves into ridiculous dance poses.
This is fun, yes, but its also VERY frustrating when your BEST weapon, has some combo attack that leaves you wide open for the enemy to steal your pants. (Or skirt, I'm not gonna judge)
However, this is remedied upon playing New-Game Plus, or completing certain storylines, where you eventually get weapons that have you fighting more seriously.

Aside from combat, there's very little in the game to expand upon...the story, although decent, is little more than an attempt to make a 'logical' reason for why you need to rip off your opponents clothes, while mixing in some 'drama' so that the dating sim part of the game works as well.
The story does its job, and rather well at that....but to judge it as a story on its own, without the gameplay. its worthless.
I also reccomend finding your own music, as the soundtrack of the game is rather plain, and the combat music is especially bad. (Though when compared directly to the above average combat itself, I guess they sorta go together)

In the end, I can really only say this, to truly summarize my entire point about this game,
Take the most droll, uninteresting, and yawn-inducing Slice of Life anime you can think of, and have it meet in the middle, with Kill La Kill.

Which, If you're like me....a noble anime fan, who is willing to accept the fact they have simple tastes, enjoy a bit of time grinding away at a game with end results that inspire a resounding Yeah~" and a self-high five; Then I'll assume you're going to like this game.

Though I imagine if you actually read this entire review. You're probably already taking this game too seriously.

3/5  Playable. Enjoyable /simple combat, depressingly tame for Jap anime.  Great visuals.

I loved this for the first hour, than just slowly had my joy for it fade as I just repeated more of the same over and over with questionable reward.  Don't get me wrong, I liked it, but didn't end up loving it. When given the option to replay a game I knocked out in almost no time at all, I just couldn't think of a reason I'd go back to it.

If you're here for traditional japanese anime boobs - forget it, there are none here, this is as PG13 as it gets, any nudity on enemies is glossed out by bright shiny animations.  As for your heroes, after you start playing they point out everyone is underage (wtf? why?) so even if you get a glimpse of underwear via the character equip screens, expect to feel just kind of gross about it.

The combat's not bad and if you're a clueless button masher like me, you can quickly find yourself in trouble facing large mobs - don't expect this to be the kind of combat you see in the Batman or Lord of the Rings games, it's 90% mash and 10% luck, but if your expectations are low, it's still fun.

Everything looks lovely, the characters are fun - and as someone who's actually been to Akihabara, the map is awesome to wander around for how much it looks like the real city.

Short version, it's worth a play if you're into cheap combat - otherwise, move along.

reviewText:
A really fun little hybrid between character action game, RPG and dating sim / visual novel. Has a fun and unique combat system and one of the few games that I actually enjoyed playing on the highest difficulty.

Akiba's Trip is full of esoteric anime and Japanese culture references, mainly due to the fact that it's a highly detailed virtual recreation of the real life Akihabara in Japan. If you want a game where you can customise your character to look almost exactly how you want it to, then this game is for you.

I found this game to have some really interesting customisation options. From the generic Torso, Legs, Head and accessory slots, there's also a slot to customise how your character walks, and how your character finishes off enemies. In addition to this, upon completing the game you gain the ability to play as nearly every character in the game as your lead character. You can also customise other lead characters in this manner.

The customisation mentioned above is obviously bare-bones at the start, as your options increase as you unlock them through playing the game. Some options can only be unlocked after clearing the game, meaning replayability is through the roof as everything is unlocked after playing through the game about 6 or 7 times.

Aside from the interesting customisation system, replayability, and fun anime / game references; the gameplay is solid, easy to understand, fun and varied.

I found my favourite part of combat was trying out all of the different makeshift weapons, as every single one has its own moveset, animations and effects in combat. From what I can tell, there are over 100 different weapons, from wooden swords to laptops and dakimakura, that's a hell of a lot of combat variety. Even with all this variety, you end up finding a moveset you love, and for me it was my trusty ol' High Quality Wooden Sword (which I upgraded to godlike" status along my several playthroughs).
